title: Springboks vs Japan: Players to look out for
text:
Sport Springboks vs Japan: Players to look out for

Kolisi must lead by example, stick to game plan for SA to avoid another shock defeat

Japan, who wrote the most improbable script of the 2015 Rugby World Cup by beating the Springboks in what was then the biggest upset in rugby, find themselves on the verge of writing more history by facing the same team in today’s quarterfinal, having already made the last eight of the ongoing tournament for the first time.

Here are three key players from each side.

JAPAN

Michael Leitch (Flank, 31)

Reports from the World Cup in Japan suggest that the Japanese captain – ironically a strong and quiet type – is now the second most recognised man in the country after the prime minister. When he comes up against the Springboks this afternoon, the powerful flanker will be among the more recognisable players to their opponents – from his Super Rugby days with the Chiefs and the “Miracle of Brighton” four years ago. The carry happy Leitch is the heart and soul of the Japanese, driving them on with each of his runs down the tramlines, with an offload and a stinging hand-off always at the ready.



Kotaro Matsushima (Wing, 26)

South Africans have been claiming Matsushima for four years since he came to prominence at the last World Cup, what with his having been born in Pretoria to a Zimbabwean father and a Japanese mother. Who wouldn’t want to claim the joint top try scoring winger at the current World Cup? Before this weekend’s matches, Matsushima was tied on five tries with Wales’ Josh Adams and within three of the tournament record of eight held by Jonah Lomu and Bryan Habana. Matsushima has been critical for Japan, scoring a hat-trick in the nervy opener against Russia, the bonus point try against Scotland and fashioning 11 clean breaks, beating 22 men and running 350m in the process.



Kazuki Himeno (Number eight, 25)

This guy has got pain in the backside written all over him. He may be the lesser-known third loose-forward in a loose-trio which includes Lappies Labuschagne and Leitch, but Himeno presents multifaceted problems. If he’s not carrying as hard as the day is long, the Sunwolves man is a thieving bastard at rucks – all of this at a relentless intensity.



SOUTH AFRICA

Siya Kolisi (Flank, 28)

If there is a criticism of the Springbok captain, it is that he can concentrate a little too much on his own game and not on the game itself. There comes a time when the skipper has to eschew the whole leading by example thing to keep his finger on the match’s pulse. Looking at how the Boks have chosen their team for this game, sticking to Rassie Erasmus’ playing script will be paramount, and Kolisi has to see to it that the game plan is implemented.



Cheslin Kolbe (Wing, 25)

Compared to Matsushima and Adams, Kolbe has only scored two tries in the competition. Yet he has still captured the imagination, thanks to a rugby intellect that is as razor sharp as he is fast and his body is agile. It’s not just his electric, “we’re coming for everything” style of play that has caught the eye, the numbers don’t lie as 15 beaten defenders and six clean breaks at almost 13m per carry tell a story.

Pieter-Steph du Toit (Flank, 27)

It speaks volumes for the kind of World Cup Kolbe has had that he has pushed Du Toit out of the limelight somewhat with his performances. But make no mistake, when there’s a big game to be won, there’s usually a big performance from Du Toit, be it through tireless carrying, an insane desire to tackle anything that moves or availing himself as a line-out option.
